pred_note: The 55-year-old African American patient visited the office after recently having new seizure episodes. This visit follows his previous one that occurred on the twenty ninth of July, 2008. The patient's recent MRI demonstrated a right contrast temporal mass. The physician expressed concerns that the mass, combined with the new seizures, could indicate a high-grade glioma. Additional tests are recommended for definitive diagnosis.
The patient reported a family history of stroke and sleep apnea.
The patient denies experiencing muscle pain, joint pain, stiffness or any weakness in muscles, and back pain. There are currently no musculoskeletal issues reported.
The patient has reported no known family history of blood or heart-related conditions or diabetes. There are also no other reported familial medical conditions.
The patient's father passed away due to a thoracic aortic aneurysm at the age of 71, and their mother died from a stroke at the age of 81.
The patient reports no changes to their medical or social history since their last visit. Their general condition appears to be good.

The patient, a 77-year-old female, presented to the clinic with shortness of breath and general discomfort. She was sedated with Ativan upon arrival due to her distressed state. The patient was unable to provide a detailed medical history at the time of admission. An immediate lung X-ray was performed, which revealed free air under her right diaphragm, indicative of a potential medical issue.

The patient reports no immediate family history of significant health conditions. Parents and two half brothers are all reported to be in good health. The patient's maternal grandmother had deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in her 40s. One paternal aunt and several maternal cousins have diabetes. Great grandfather on an unspecified side had bone cancer in his eighties. The patient's maternal uncle has been recently diagnosed with leukemia at around fifty years old. The patient's paternal grandfather had colon cancer from the age of sixty-eight until his death at seventy-three.

The patient is a retired social security administration employee who stays physically active through regular travel with his wife. He occasionally drinks alcohol socially but denies any use of tobacco or illicit drugs.
The patient has reported no known allergies to any medications.

The patient is a 79-year-old African American female who is 5'3" in height and weighs about 197 pounds. She has a known medical history of Type 2 diabetes since 1983. She has not reported any known allergies to medications so far.

The patient, originally from the Philippines, has had his BCG vaccine prior to starting elementary school. Immunization records have been submitted to the office. He has been experiencing stomach uneasiness for a few days. There is no history of liver problems, gallbladder stones, or ulcers. His previous physical examination and blood tests were normal. He has no recent experiences of fever or chills.
The patient lives alone but has a strong support system through their family and friends. They admitted to using tobacco products and suggested some reluctance to quit. They do not consume alcohol.

The patient indicates they've generally been feeling good. They have recently started therapy to manage anxiety and have a scheduled session with a psychiatrist next week. There have been no issues with blood pressure; the patient is compliant with their medication regimen which seems to be effective.
The patient has expressed concerns regarding their liver health due to their high consumption of Tylenol for pain. The patient denies partaking in alcohol consumption or smoking.

The patient reported no current complaints during the review of systems, with a negative review for headaches, breathlessness, skin problems, and chest or any other pains. The patient had no new or significant symptoms to report.

The patient denies experiencing any notable changes in skin color, such as blue or greyish discoloration. They also report no swelling, including no water-like retention or perceptible swelling in the fingers or toes.
The patient has a history of good health with no record of any significant health issues or surgical experiences. The reason for the current visit has not been specified.

The patient is experiencing persistent fatigue. The primary concern could be a result of several underlying conditions which the patient is suffering from--hypertension, high cholesterol, and osteoarthritis. Doctor has advised the patient to have a more cautious approach to their health management regarding these conditions. Long-term care or management plans to be discussed further.

The patient, a white female working as a secretary, presented for a routine follow-up from her August 10, 2004 visit. She reported improvement in her acne treatment, but has been experiencing a rash on her chest, stomach, neck, and back for the last two months, identified as small folliculitis lesions related to her acne. The doctor confirmed that she had temporarily ceased her medication regime, which includes 500mg Amoxicillin twice a day and 0.1% Tazorac cream. She noted improvements in her facial acne from this medication and has also sought additional treatment in the form of photofacials from Healing Waters. She expressed interest in receiving more rapid treatment or other skin care products to enhance her appearance. The doctor recommended continuing her current medication, advising against stopping its intake.

The patient has been experiencing chronic toe numbness and periodic leg swelling. Their mobility is severely limited due to their weight and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), leading to shortness of breath upon attempting to get up. They take OxyContin for consistent back pain, but report no gastrointestinal symptoms. The patient additionally reports having oozing leg sores.

The patient reported new-onset chest pain that they have been experiencing for the last few nights. The pain is described as a gnawing sensation and usually lasts a few seconds. The patient's self-rating of the pain intensity is 5-6 out of 10. The patient has not taken any medication for the pain. Other than the chest pain, the patient reports no additional symptoms such as shortness of breath or leg swelling. The patient alluded to other conditions which are followed up routinely, but did not specify the details.

The patient has been married for 45 years. He is a retired individual living in a house near the waterfront. The patient stopped smoking around 1997 and he occasionally consumes alcohol, mostly in the form of wine or beer.
The patient has past medical history of sinus problems and suffered a stroke approximately two years ago. The patient denies any history of smoking or alcohol use, and has no known allergies.

The doctor advised the patient to follow a low sodium diet due to a currently unspecified medical condition. The patient has been specifically advised to avoid foods high in salt, such as chips, junk food, and pickles. The patient has verbally consented to follow this dietary advice.
The patient's paternal family has a history of psoriasis and the maternal side has a history of arthritis. The patient does not have a personal history of arthritis or any childhood diseases.

The 68-year-old patient with a history of ischemic cardiac disease came in for a reevaluation of his heart health. His previous medical examination in February 2004, administered by doctor X Y Z, involved a treadmill test that lasted eight minutes. The scan from this test showed some heart wall scarring, although the patient's cardiac output was reportedly normal. The patient denied experiencing any symptoms such as chest pain, palpitations, difficulty sleeping, extremity swelling, or orthopnea.
The patient reported experiencing symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea and fever.
Guest clinician stated that the patient they previously discussed was discharged and went home. No further medical information or updates about the patient's health were provided in the conversation.
The patient has a history of metastatic prostate cancer that disseminated to different parts of his body.
The patient has a family history of arthritis, with their father having arthritis in both hips. There were no other significant familial medical conditions reported.

The 55-year-old patient has been experiencing weakness in his right leg for approximately six months. He reported having difficulty standing on his right toe and pushing off while walking. Additionally, he noticed a persistent, mild tingling and numbness in his toes. He has also been experiencing mild back pain for several years and cramping in both calves which stopped about two months ago, with no mentioned weakness in his left leg. The patient denied any radicular pain or bowel or bladder incontinence. His condition has been the same since the symptoms started, without progression or alleviation. He has an ear implant which doesn't allow for MRI scanning. An EMG and nerve conduction studies were conducted and a CT scan didn't show anything abnormal except for degenerative changes. Concerning medications, the patient recently stopped taking Lipitor due to increased CK levels and started Zetia (no associated symptoms with starting this medication) and does not report any new weakness or pain after starting Zetia. His exact CK levels before the medication change were in the 500s and 600s, which increased after starting and then reduced after halting Lipitor consumption. The patient first saw a doctor for these symptoms in October.

The doctor consulted Poison Control about a possible ingestion incident involving the patient. Poison Control indicated that the quantity involved was relatively small and probable ingestion of the liquid would likely be non-toxic. The patient's behavior demonstrated she likely did not ingest any liquid.
The patient denied both smoking and alcohol consumption. No current habits regarding tobacco or alcohol use identified.
The patient reports having well-controlled diabetes. He has also been diagnosed with Hepatitis C and HIV.

The patient reported being allergic to Bactrim, leading to side effects like nausea and vomiting. He also indicated a potential allergy to adhesive tape, as the use of such causes him to develop a skin rash almost immediately.

A 56-year-old female patient presented with foot pain resulting from a twist injury she incurred on November 26, 2007 at approximately 11:30 AM. She does not recall the specific details of the event. She reports having no other concurrent injuries.

The patient reported a history of daily smoking for the past fifteen years, with an average of one pack a day. They also confessed a substance abuse problem, including addiction to prescription painkillers such as OxyContin, as well as other narcotics obtained illegally. In addition, the patient admitted to heavy alcohol consumption. The patient indicated a need for assistance in combating these addictions.

The 36-year-old white female patient complained of persisting pain in her left knee, which restricts her from fully bending or straightening it out. The utilization of her entire body weight exacerbates the severity of the pain. Despite undergoing three Synvisc injections (most recent five days ago), there's only been a moderate improvement, estimated at 35-40%. Her pain level was rated as a maximum pain intensity of 10/10. Pain management methods used include alternating ice and heat, along with the use of Tylenol with codeine (prescribed) and over-the-counter ibuprofen. The effect of these methods to alleviate pain has unfortunately been minimal.

The patient confirms that there have been no changes in their health or lifestyle parameters since their last visit. They report no history of smoking, drinking, or drug use. Additionally, the patient has no medical conditions or undergone any surgeries in the past. All information corresponds with the data previously reported in their medical and social history.

The patient had a follow-up discussion with the doctor about their recent medical condition. Their previous intestine infection, specifically C Diff colitis, has been successfully resolved, as confirmed by Doctor X, who the patient saw two weeks prior. Additionally, the patient received a confirmation about their ongoing medical conditions of hypertension and high cholesterol.
The patient presents with symptoms of congestion and suspected fever, noticing an elevated temperature upon touching their forehead. No further symptoms or details were discussed.

A 68-year-old patient presented to the emergency department with a main complaint of a bad cough producing green and grey sputum for three days. They denied experiencing any shortness of breath, fever, or chills. Despite these symptoms, the patient's respiratory distress was not apparent.
Upon evaluation, an abdominal examination was performed and it was determined that there were no signs of any identifiable intra-abdominal pathology.

The patient has a self-reported history of obesity and suffers from hypertension (high blood pressure). They had a past surgical procedure in 1990 to repair a right knee fracture with a pin fixation. The patient also indicated they have a history of blood clots.

The patient confirmed they were placed on a nasogastric tube for decompression therapy. Following the treatment, the patient reported feeling slightly better, suggesting potential progress or positive response to the therapy.

The patient has been suffering from congestion for several years, potentially due to enlarged adenoids or an anatomical feature. They saw an ENT specialist about this issue a year ago, but they have no immediate plans to revisit. The doctor recommended scheduling another appointment with the ENT. The patient also reported discomfort from an ingrown toenail. Upon inspection, the doctor noted that it appears to be improving autonomously.

A two-month-old baby girl presented with congestion lasting for a week. Additionally, she has been running a fever for the past two days. No reported symptoms of difficulty breathing or wheezing as per the family. The family noted a reduced milk intake and an approximate three to four diaper changes daily.
The patient, a non-smoker, reported experiencing a headache that began earlier in the day, which they attribute to a stressful domestic environment involving their spouse and children.

The 77-year-old white female patient had a follow-up consultation with her doctor. Her background medical history includes low back pain, lumbar scoliosis post-laminectomy syndrome, lumbar spinal stenosis, and symptomatic right L2 radiculopathy. She had a laminectomy surgery due to spinal stenosis. The patient recounted post-operative pain and arthritis in her spine, treated by Doctor XYZ with injections into her lower back, specifically on the right side, L2-L3, with the last one administered in March 2005.Following the injections, the doctor thought her symptoms were originating from her right hip. An imaging had been done on the hip in August 2004. The patient's recent x-ray shows marked degenerative changes and progression since the last x-ray. Additionally, she also received injections in her right hip with the last injection given in April 2005.However, she is still experiencing significant pain in her right hip, specifically when she puts weight on it, and is using a cane to help. There have been discussions about a hip replacement, but the patient remains undecided. She has an appointment scheduled with an orthopedist in Newton.She is currently on the generic form of Ultracet, taking it up to four times daily for pain management, but expressed that she is still in significant pain.

The patient presents with a history of a frequently injured left wrist, most recently aggravated when lifting items out of a car trunk. The pain has been described as fluctuating in severity, but the latest incident seems to have intensified the pain and localized it more towards the ulnar (pinky) side of the wrist rather than radial (thumb) side. Medical records indicate chronic scapholunate problems along with other unspecified issues in the same wrist. Treatment plans to address the ligament damage are to be developed.
The patient confirmed that they are currently not taking any medications.
The patient has no known medical allergies according to the feedback received from the family.

The patient is a widowed retiree who lives alone. He maintains an active lifestyle by walking about four miles daily. He reports that he does not use any substances like tobacco, alcohol, or illegal drugs. The patient lost his wife six months ago.

**The patient is checking blood sugar levels twice daily and records the readings. They are not experiencing any symptoms such as dizziness, excessive urination, fatigue, or weight loss. However, the patient's cholesterol levels remain high and they have been advised to continue with the prescribed cholesterol medication and monitor their cholesterol intake. Another follow up appointment has been scheduled to check progress after a few weeks. Regarding previously reported sinus issues, the patient seems to be responding well to the Z Pak treatment and showed improvements.

The patient presented with ongoing stomach issues, specifically experiencing diarrhea over the past several weeks. The frequency of these episodes is about five to six times daily. Further evaluation required to identify the underlying cause.

The patient has not reported any issues with their eyesight, specifically denying occurrences of double vision, blurred vision, partial loss of vision, or blind spots. Hence, no apparent ophthalmological issues.

The patient reports experiencing episodes of disorientation, including one recent incident where they could not remember where they were driving while in transit. These episodes appear to last around 10-15 minutes. Similar episodes have occurred two other times. The doctor has recommended a referral to a specialist to conduct more extensive cognitive testing to better understand the patient's condition.

The patient reports experiencing occasional overactive bladder symptoms, but denies having any associated pain with urination or other urinary symptoms. The symptoms tend to occur during times of high stress. There were no reports of abdominal pain, excessive thirst or eating, constipation, diarrhea, heartburn, chest pain or tightness, shortness of breath, headaches, or fever. The patient also reported no issues with skin, muscles, or joints. The clinician plans to order an ultrasound of the kidneys and run a urine test for further investigation of the patient's urinary concerns.
The patient reported a family history of asthma, with a mother and two aunts having long-term diagnoses. The patient denied any history of kidney diseases or rheumatological disorders in the family.

The doctor confirmed that the patient's EKG showed a normal rhythm with a slightly leftward axis, which is considered a normal variation and doesn't require further treatment. The patient's Complete Blood Count (CBC) and Basic Metabolic Panel (BMP) results were normal. Their cardiac enzymes test was negative. The patient acknowledged understanding the explanations provided.
The patient is currently taking Amoxil and Aldex, which they began taking on Monday. They are not on any other medications.

The patient, a 17-year-old female, had a 2 millimeter fishbone obstructing her airways. This necessitated immediate intubation and a surgical procedure in the operating room to remove the foreign object.

The patient, who has high lipid levels, high blood pressure, and potential metabolic syndrome, came in to discuss their diet. The patient had been given a meal plan but reported difficulty in following it. The patient believes they were gaining weight instead of losing it despite their efforts. Their physical activity includes regular walking and gardening, which they do regularly as part of their daily chores. The patient, unsatisfied with the meal plan's effects, reverted to the South Beach Diet and saw some weight loss. However, they do not believe this diet to be healthy in the long-term. The patient is seeking a revised diet plan to effectively lose weight while incorporating low-fat choices. As a next step, the doctor proposed setting a new plan aimed at these goals.

The patient presented with new onset shortness of breath, chiefly noticeable during moments of exertion, occurring over the past three days. There is a notable absence of additional symptoms such as leg pain, swelling, or chest pain. The patient does not have a history of asthma. Their pulse oximetry reading was in the high nineties, presently eliminating the need for supplemental oxygen. Nonetheless, due to the concern raised by these symptoms, the doctor has recommended a CT scan of the patient's chest to establish the root cause.

The patient reported feeling much better during the latest follow-up with the doctor. The doctor informed the patient that they had been treated with the seventh cycle of chemotherapy, specifically with ifosphomide, mesna, and VP 16. The patient expressed confusion about the names and possible implications of these medications.

The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, anemia, IBS, bowel abnormalities, and bouts of diarrhea due to a C.diff infection. Currently, the patient's blood sugar and anemia are well-managed. The patient has not experienced any new or odd symptoms related to fever, chills, weight fluctuation, changes in vision or hearing, excessive thirst, urination, respiratory issues, chest pain, heart issues, urinary problems, vaginal bleeding, or neurological problems. The patient reported no new issues with anemia and confirmed that their weight has been stable. The patient's recent episodes of diarrhea have seen improvement.

The 56-year-old right-handed patient reported a persistent on and off lower back pain on the right side, which began after a motor vehicle accident in 2005. The pain, described as "abnormal," started five days post-accident and has been progressively increasing. It radiates from the lower right side of the back spreading to the posterior side of the thighs and the outside of the calf. The patient noted that prolonged periods of sitting or walking exacerbate the pain, while standing or lying down somewhat alleviate it. No reports of weakness or pain in either leg, and no changes in bowel movements or urine functions were reported. Treatment with painkillers such as Medrol and an unspecified injection in the back (administered around 4.5 weeks prior) showed negligible relief. The physical examination by the doctor showed full strength in the legs and symmetry. The straight leg raise test was normal.
The patient is presently married and engaged in part-time farming work. They have reported no intake of alcohol, use of tobacco, or use of any kind of drugs.
The patient has no past surgical history. She confirmed that she has never undergone any surgery, including joint replacements or C-sections. All of her births have been natural.
The patient is currently taking multiple medications including Morphine, Darvocet, Flomax, Avodart, and Ibuprofen. The medication list has been recently updated by a nurse.
The patient was reported to be in good general appearance. They were well-developed and well-nourished, and showed no signs of acute distress.
The patient reported no known family medical history of any health problems.

The patient reported experiencing pain on the upper right side of his chest. This pain is accompanied by occasional nausea and a significant decrease in the patient's appetite. However, the patient has not had vomiting, fever, diarrhea, headache, joint pain, seizures, loss of consciousness, or stroke-like symptoms. A review of the patient's past medical and surgical history was conducted but the patient reported no family history of similar chest pain.

The 68-year-old female patient presented with a history of knee pain for the last thirteen years. She had a previous knee replacement operation to address the pain, but is now considering another surgery due to recurring symptoms. She reports intense pain, a sensation of snapping, difficulty walking, and a feeling that her knee is giving way. X-ray results confirm some malalignment of the hardware from her previous surgery.

The patient in question is in good health with no symptoms of heart disease or failure, and has had normal blood sugar levels recently. The patient has been seeing another doctor, Doctor X, and is reported as doing well. No recent falls have been reported. The patient experiences occasional pain in the right knee, which is managed with Tylenol. The patient has asked about the possibility of a knee brace. Regular bathroom use was confirmed, with no incontinence. The patient reports no issues with memory.
The doctor examined the patient's breast tissue and confirmed it was normal for males, affirming there were no related health concerns.

The patient has recently started following a protein-rich diet, consuming whey protein and various greens. The doctor observed a positive change in the patient's appearance, likely the result of this new dietary regimen, and encouraged the patient to continue with their current diet.

The patient has a history of UTIs, but reported no current urinary symptoms. They have been increasing their water intake and taking preventative measures since becoming bed-bound. There are currently no fever or chills, and the patient's weight is stable. No experiences of coughing, chest congestion, or chest pain were reported. The patient denied shortness of breath, any type of bleeding from the rectum, constipation, stomach pain, nausea, or vomiting.
The patient has a history of prostate cancer. He has also experienced intermittent issues with urinary incontinence. He has undergone a surgical procedure for left hip replacement.
The patient is currently not restrained but does utilize a palm protector in her right hand as per doctor's observation.

The patient, who lives with his wife, is a current tobacco user and smokes less than one pack of cigarettes per day. He denies any alcohol or recreational drug use. He is currently unemployed and has been for several months, he previously worked as an IT software developer.
The patient reported a family history of both high blood pressure and diabetes, indicating multiple affected relatives.
The patient reported mild soreness in the left arm due to a recent vaccination. All other aspects of the Review of Systems (ROS) were noted to be normal.

The patient reported feeling much better following treatment with Prednisone. The symptoms, including redness and swelling, appear to have decreased significantly. The patient confirmed this was their first wasp sting.
The patient has no recollection of any previous surgeries; therefore, no surgical history can be recorded at this point.
The patient has denied any history of psychiatric disorders, including depression and mood disorders, during the conversation with the doctor.

The patient's mother and sister were present during the consultation. There were suspicions raised about potential drug use, including consumption of marijuana, though it was uncertain which specific substances she may have taken. The doctor expressed similar concerns. Further investigation into the patient's substance use history is needed.

The patient reported no gastrointestinal issues, no symptoms beyond those previously discussed, and no heart, genital or urinary tract problems. They also described their range of motion as normal, despite wanting to be more flexible. They reported no muscle or movement issues.

The patient is currently on disability and living with his girlfriend. He acknowledges that his activity of daily living is minimal and he requires assistance for basic self-care tasks from his girlfriend. He reports not indulging in alcohol or tobacco use and does not recall the date of his last drug test.

The patient has never been hospitalized, but had a severe skateboarding accident approximately two years ago. The patient has been skateboarding since childhood, roughly around the age of 8 or 9, and usually skateboards at a skatepark with friends.

The patient is a 75-year-old female, who has been experiencing increasing weakness, shakiness, and dyspnea, particularly when walking. She reported that these symptoms have been present for a considerable period but have recently worsened. No signs of chest pain, palpitations, cough, bloody sputum, wheezing, or fainting were reported.

The patient is suffering from periodic migraines, which may worsen due to weather changes. Currently, the patient is not seeing any specialist but agreed to look for a neurologist. The doctor recommends a neurology consultation for a second opinion and advised getting a brain scan. The patient plans to make an appointment in the near future.

The patient reported no chest pain or shortness of breath during the consultation. There were also no indications of any bleeding disorder or prolonged bleeding. The treating physician already has the patient's gastrointestinal and urinary tract reports on file, and no additional reports or symptoms were mentioned by the patient.
The patient has a past surgical history of a repaired right intertrochanteric femur fracture.

The patient is an 85-year-old male/female who visited the clinic complaining of muscle pain in the right buttocks region, potentially radiating from the lower back or spine. It is an irritating pain that isn't characterized as sharp or dull. The patient visited the renal clinic four months ago but reports feeling significantly better in terms of managing their high blood pressure. The patient denies any side effects from their current medication, as well as any other discomfort, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, weakness, dizziness, lightheadedness, constipation, stomach pain, shortness of breath, or chest pain. The patient exercises within the same range as before. The patient tried Tylenol for the hip pain but it only temporarily alleviated the pain. The doctor decided to try a stronger medication and said to return in one week if the pain doesn't improve, at which point they may consider x-ray imaging.
The patient reported having no known drug allergies.

The patient reported a fun weekend where she attended a party but has since been experiencing back pain. She confirmed occasional alcohol consumption, only during special occasions. A recent event was such an occasion where she admits to having consumed a small amount of alcohol.

The patient denies personal history of heart disease and diabetes, but reports having high blood pressure. They also deny any known family history of heart disease, diabetes or hypertension. The doctor notes that the patient's recent bloodwork resulted in borderline elevated cholesterol levels. The patient was advised to return in one month for a follow-up cholesterol level check.
The patient reported no experience of any symptoms as of their most recent consultation with the doctor.

The two-month-old patient has been experiencing severe congestion and an increase in coughing, along with episodes of irregular, rapid breathing. The patient's coughing has triggered a reflex that causes her to spit up or vomit and the same happens after feeding sessions. The patient has not been feeding well, resulting in fewer wet diapers. She has been running a fever between 102 and 104 degrees Fahrenheit. There is no report of diarrhea. It's notable that the patient's sibling has an upper respiratory infection, which started out a day or two before the patient's symptoms.
The patient takes multivitamins and calcium supplements regularly. No prescription medications were reported.
The patient came in reporting a boil-like issue located on their buttocks. Further examination and discussion are needed for formal diagnosis and treatment options.

The patient reports these repeating symptoms: a feeling of twitching and grimacing in her face and mouth, a weekly sensation of pins and needles, and pressure in the back of the head, akin to water running down her hair, that is partially relieved by Aleve. These symptoms have notably decreased in recent times. The patient also experiences excessive daytime sleepiness and tends to fall asleep in non-stimulating environments. Despite this, the patient reports difficulty falling asleep after work (working hours are 4 PM to midnight) and typically only attains 5 to 6 hours of sleep, despite a two-hour period required to fall asleep after arriving home. The quality of this sleep is reported to be good, with the exception of needing to use the restroom. Possible snoring was mentioned, though it's unconfirmed. No episodes of disrupted sleep due to breathing problems were reported.
The patient reports having had surgical procedures on their foot and knee. In addition, the patient recalls undergoing abdominal surgery. No additional surgical history was discussed.

The patient came for a routine annual physical check-up. No new symptoms or issues were reported. The patient confirmed that their social history and past medical conditions have remained unchanged since their last visit.
The patient reported no known drug allergies.

The 56-year-old white male patient presented with a lump in his chest on the left side that has been present for at least a year. The lump has increased in size and has become tender, causing discomfort when the patient takes deep breaths.

The patient presented with bilateral ear pain and has been expelling green snot for approximately six days. On examination, the doctor noticed fluid accumulation in the right middle ear. The doctor suspects sinusitis. The patient was prescribed antibiotics and a follow-up visit was scheduled to monitor fluid clearance from the ear.
The patient has reported no known allergies.

The 2.5-year-old patient, with a history of seizures, is on a medication regime of Keppra solution 150 MG, twice daily. This treatment was effective in reducing seizure episodes. Recently, the parents report her displaying symptoms of a potential absence seizure, where she would cease activity and stare blankly for duration varying from 10 seconds to 4 minutes as reported by different family members. During a specific episode, her skin around the mouth turned blue. The patient displayed no jerky motions or loss of body control during these episodes. The medication dosage hasn't been changed recently. However, the doctor noted from the patient's records that her current daily dosage of 20 MG per kilogram might be low. No changes in medication amounts or schedule are reported by the family.
The patient reported a history of alcoholism in their family, specifically mentioning their grandfather. No other familial medical conditions were discussed.
The patient is currently on medication for anxiety and is also taking estrogen. Specifically, anxiety medication is being administered though the exact name of the medication was not mentioned.
The patient confirms an allergy to Sulfa drugs. Upon exposure to these drugs, the patient experiences severe dizziness and uncontrollable vomiting.
The patient confirmed that they are the only person in their family known to suffer from heart problems. There is no recorded family history of heart conditions.

The patient presented for a routine check-up and reported experiencing widespread joint pain for the past couple of weeks. The patient attempted self-treatment with Advil, achieving minimal symptom relief.

The patient has been experiencing headaches, for which they have not taken any prescribed drugs. They have been self-managing the headaches with over-the-counter medications including Excedrin and ibuprofen. However, these over-the-counter medications have not been effective in providing relief.
This is the patient's first pregnancy. She exhibits positive emotions about the upcoming birth of her child.
Patient denies use of tobacco and alcohol.
The patient is a mother of three healthy children who live with her and her boyfriend. The patient denies any tobacco or drug use, but admits to occasional alcohol consumption.

The patient reported ongoing issues with her right hand for several weeks. Symptoms include intermittent sensations of pins and needles, numbness, and pain, primarily affecting her middle finger but occasionally the first or second fingers and her thumb. The patient noted these symptoms get worse at night and this has started to impact her mental health. She works in an office and spends most of the day at a computer keyboard, which led her to adjust her workstation recently in hopes of relief. Despite concerns about potential carpal tunnel or arthritis, the doctor suggested further tests to confirm a diagnosis.
The patient reported discontinuation of Prevacid due to the experience of an adverse effect, which was diarrhea.

The patient's urinary bag was recently changed and the urine was sent to the lab for testing. No signs of infection were found in the urine as indicated by the absence of leukocytes. However, blood was noticed during catheterization but the urine returned to normal afterwards. Furthermore, the patient's x-ray showed the presence of stool in the colon. Despite this, the overall health of the patient was good and he was observed to be very active.
The patient reported no known familial history of medical issues. They further indicated that they do not partake in alcohol consumption or smoking.

The patient is currently stable but unable to provide a medical history at the moment. The guest clinician has requested to be notified when the patient is awake and able to respond to questions, and they will be available on the eighth floor.

The patient is diagnosed with Serotonin syndrome, as indicated by her high white cell count and CPK levels. The patient confirms symptoms consistent with this diagnosis - restlessness, agitation, and diarrhea, but denies fever or shakiness. The doctor administered IV fluids which appeared to improve her condition, as her CPK counts improved and her white blood cell counts have reduced, nearly normal now. The drug Prozac was discontinued.  The patient also reveals that she has a history of panic attacks, depression, and anxiety, which have worsened since her husband left her two weeks ago. Her doctor has consulted with a psychiatrist and prescribed Cymbalta as an alternative to Prozac. She intends to meet with the psychiatrist in the following week and is also seeing a counselor.   The patient is experiencing some difficulty with her current living situation and will be staying with a friend for the next three days. Her daughter will also visit in two weeks. The patient confirms she has been adhering to her medication regimen for co-existing conditions of high blood pressure and diabetes. Improved symptoms observed post-treatment include resolution of diarrhea.

A 46-year-old female patient with a history of epilepsy has reported experiencing symptoms which she believes may be indicative of small seizures, including morning body aches, confusion upon waking, and unexplained periods of weakness during the day at work. She lives and works alone, so there have been no observed seizure events. Given her history and reported symptoms, the clinician recommended conducting a video EEG test today to gain more insight into whether the patient is experiencing epileptic seizures or non-epileptic events. The patient agreed to the EEG test and has the time for the procedure to be done today.
The doctor followed up with the patient after a nasogaic tube was placed for decompression. The patient, as communicated by a family member, reported feeling better following the procedure.

The patient, who is suffering from prostate cancer that has metastasized to other parts of his body including the bladder, spine, and shoulder, reports noticing a recurrence of blood in his urine. The blood in his urine was first noticed the day prior and was still present at the time of his appointment. There has been no change in his chronic lower back pain, and he denied any incidence of incontinence, fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or presence of blood in stools. He confirmed that he is not having any difficulty in urination or bowel movements. He has completed chemotherapy and has started radiation therapy aimed at reducing the pain in his bones, rather than curing the cancer. Conversation about planning for hospice care was initiated by the doctor, and the patient expressed willingness to consider hospice facilities.

The patient reported discomfort on the right side under the ribs. Historical health issues include a reaction causing hives, a two-year history of dialysis, and persistent high blood pressure. The doctor suspects that the patient's renal issues and hypertension could be related and intends to investigate further.
The doctor diagnosed a foreign body in the patient's left eye. The family of the patient inquired about the necessity of a further consultation with an eye specialist.

The patient is currently experiencing an elevated fever which is suspected by the doctor and a guest clinician to be causing a febrile seizure. The patient's family is concerned about his condition. Further examination and assessment of the patient's condition is planned by the medical team.
The patient occasionally consumes wine with dinner but has no history of tobacco or drug use.

The patient denies regular alcohol consumption, only occasionally consuming alcohol for special events. The patient also denies any history of drug usage. They do not smoke and have never smoked in the past.
The patient confirmed being asked previously about their medications. The doctor then confirmed from the patient's medical chart that the patient is not taking any blood thinners.

The patient is a 26-year-old African American male who experienced a pop in the back of his left leg after stepping off a hilo at work. Post injury, he was put in a splint and was advised to follow-up with the doctor at ABC orthopedics. He did not mention any other treatments.

The physician and parent discussed the condition of the child, who has been displaying unusual behaviors such as an obsession with cleanliness, asking a surplus of questions, and collecting old toys. The child has been having difficulty relating to peers in the classroom and has shown signs of confusion and depression. However, the frequency of question-asking behavior has decreased recently. This summer, the child is enrolled in a social skills program. According to the parent, the child has been referred to two psychologists for functional behavioral analysis by A B C D. The child is currently taking 7.5 MG of Abilify; he is no longer taking Zoloft, and as a result, has seen some improvement in hand tremors. The doctor stressed the importance of continuing follow-ups with the psychologists.

The patient confirmed having had a recent visit with their cardiologist, following a bypass surgery they underwent few months ago. They reported that no other family members are known to suffer from heart disease. Their most recent EKG results were normal according to the physician.
The patient confirmed that they are not currently on any medication. This was previously discussed with the nurse and now documented by the doctor in the Electronic Health Record (EHR).

The patient is a one-year-old girl of Tanzanian descent who was presented to our dermatology office by her mother. She was referred by the A B C Practice, having recently moved from Tanzania. She has a known history of atopic eczema for which she has been using Elidel cream twice daily for the past six months. The effectiveness of the cream has recently declined as per mother's assessment, with the patient now experiencing dry skin. The mother is currently applying Johnson's Baby oil on her skin. The patient otherwise appears well-developed and in good health. Future plans include exploring alternative treatments for the patient's rashes.
The patient reported no known allergies during the consult.

The patient, a healthcare worker, reported accidentally being jabbed by a needle while working with a patient. The patient they were working with tested negative for HIV, but positive for Hepatitis C (noted to be a carrier without symptoms). The worker had been coming in for regular screenings and expressed anxiety over the incident. The physician noted prior Hepatitis B vaccinations and a tetanus shot on record for the worker. There is a presence of antibodies as per the latest tests, conducted on February 7th, 2005. The worker's liver function test was found to be normal, with no signs of Hepatitis C or HIV. The worker reported no local signs of infection, but disclosed having some acute intestinal problem such as squeakiness and vomiting. Physical examination conducted by the doctor revealed a fine abdomen with no fever or swelling.
The patient reported feelings of significant weakness and shakiness. No further symptoms or health concerns were discussed in this particular dialogue.
The patient is seeking treatment for cancer. The patient's family history is significant for cancer, with two brothers and their father also having some form of the disease.
The patient lives with her husband and is frequently checked on by her daughter and son-in-law, who live next door. She reports no usage of ethanol, tobacco, or illicit substances.

The patient has a family history of cancer, specifically metastatic breast cancer in the patient's mother and bone cancer in the maternal aunt. The patient's family also has an extensive history of diabetes, with an onset during adulthood, indicative of adult onset diabetes mellitus. This history spans both sides of the patient's family.

The patient is a 5.5-year-old boy who first experienced a dual fracture in his forearm in September 2007. He subsequently rebroke the same forearm a month prior to this consultation. Post the fracture, he had surgery which involved the insertion of an ulnar nail. The doctor confirmed that the nail, which is now prominently visible under the skin, needs early removal. Post removal, the patient will need to wear a cast for approximately three additional weeks. The patient's mother was reassured about the low risk of infection (less than 1%) as antibiotics will be administrated during and post-surgery. Other surgical risks such as bleeding, sensory changes in the extremity, and possible necessity for extended cast usage were discussed. It was also confirmed that the patient will be anaesthetized for the surgery.

The patient is reported to take three different medications daily. This includes Aspirin, a medication for blood pressure, and a diabetes medication. The specifics of the latter two medications are not stated, but the doctor has examined the medication labels directly.

The patient, a two-week-old newborn, was brought in by the family due to a concern regarding the appearance of his foreskin. The physician performed an examination and found no abnormalities. The child has been otherwise well and there are no other health issues reported by the family.

The patient reported a family history of stroke and heart conditions, with his mother passing away from a stroke and his father having heart problems in addition to high blood pressure. The patient had a personal history of heavy smoking approximately two to three packs per day before quitting in 1990. The patient's past occupation was as a feed salesman which he has been doing most of his adult life.

The patient, an 18-month-old Swedish American male, had been experiencing a fever (highest noted reading of 102.6 degrees Fahrenheit) for five days, higher during the nights and recently has been showing signs of improvement. He had been taking Amoxil for a sinus infection and also takes Zyrtec for allergies. Additionally, the patient shows symptoms of teething, including drooling and fussiness. Mucous discharge from the patient's nose is discolored in the morning but clears up throughout the day. There was no reported diarrhea, vomiting, or coughing, and his appetite remains normal.
The patient underwent a surgical procedure approximately seven or eight years ago. It was related to a disc issue in the patient's back. The patient does not recall any other past surgeries.

The patient, Miss XYZ, was previously diagnosed with flexor carpi radialis (FCR) tendinitis by Doctor A B C, which is inflammation in a forearm tendon. For treatment, she has received two cortisone shots and uses anti-inflammatories for pain management. She also plays instruments, an activity that occasionally exacerbates her symptoms. The patient expresses uncertainty about pursuing surgery, a topic that she hopes to discuss with the doctor.
The patient reported a family history of diabetes, specifically noting that their father had had the disease.

The patient presented with widespread chronic pain, which he associated with multiple past physical injuries. He has a history of heroin use, evidenced by past treatment records from Doctor X Y Z. The patient confirmed his relapse into heroin use as a coping mechanism for the chronic pain. He also stated that episodes of intense pain trigger his cravings for the drug. Immediate care and a suitable pain management plan should be considered to support the patient's substance use disorder and chronic pain conditions.

The patient, a 47-year-old white female, reported a suspected spider bite on the back left side of her shoulder. The patient first noticed the bite two days ago, describing it as tender and red, and has grown in size since. In addition, she observed red streaks going up her neck from the bite. Upon inquiry, the patient mentioned slight pain upon physical touch, but denied experiencing any fever since the bite occurred.
The patient denies any past surgeries, including gallbladder or appendix removal, and joint replacements.

The patient resides with his family, which consists of his parents and two younger sisters. They engage in regular family activities such as game nights weekly and frequent weekend hikes. The patient reported no known contact with anyone who is currently ill.

The doctor assessed the patient's shoulder x-ray, which consisted of two views. No signs of bone abnormalities or degenerative changes were observed. The result is considered normal, indicating no current issues in the shoulder area.

Patient, a 51-year-old male, presented at ABCD General Hospital with diagnosed degenerative joint disease (arthritis) of the metatarsophalangeal joint (MPJ) of the big toe. Radiographic evidence confirms this diagnosis. The patient reports progressively worsening pain at the site. Surgical intervention is suggested by the doctor and the patient expresses intent to proceed with the surgery.
The patient reports a diagnosis of Parkinson's disease which was given by Dr. Johnson five years prior. No additional medical information is provided.
The patient had a history of recurrent tonsil infections, for which the tonsils were surgically removed.

During the patient's visit, her main concern was to reduce facial wrinkles. The patient is 57 years old, does not smoke, and has no known history of skin disease. Upon examination, the doctor observed that her submandibular and mid-face regions are predominantly full and she has prominent nasolabial folds. The patient expressed desire to look younger, but no specific treatment or procedure was discussed or agreed upon during this visit.

The patient, a 38-year-old woman, is a new comer and complains of hip pain which is more intense on the right side. The pain has been present for approximately two years and has been escalating in severity. Recently, the left hip has started to experience similar pain. The pain is localized to the front and side of the hip region, extending into the groin. Activities like walking exacerbate the discomfort, and she additionally reports new symptoms of popping and clicking sounds. Despite the duration of the condition, this is her first medical consultation regarding this issue.

The 53-year-old female patient has a confirmed diagnosis of a herniated disc at T8-T9. The condition is causing her to experience rib pain. She attempted to manage the discomfort with rest and anti-inflammatory medications, but these methods have not been effective. The patient is interested in exploring surgical options for relief from the persistent pain.
The patient informed the doctor about their existing condition of high blood pressure. No other chronic diseases were mentioned.

A 58-year-old female patient reported sudden onset of vision loss, slurred speech, and tongue numbness on January 8, 1993. The vision impairment slightly improved on her way to a local Emergency Room (ER), but worsened again upon arrival. During evaluation, she fell unresponsive and didn't respond to deep noxious stimuli. This was the first occurrence of such symptoms. She was transferred to UIHC, where she showed marked improvement in her condition.

The patient reported no history of depression or depression-like symptoms in their immediate family. However, he/she noted that a second cousin has experienced depression and a subsequent nervous breakdown.

The patient presented with E. coli which showed signs of improvement at the follow-up visit. However, she experienced complications while on medication (Macrobid), which included skin rash and hives. This led to discontinuation of the medicine. The symptoms resolved upon stopping the medication. She reported no pain during urination or presence of blood in urine, no fever or chills. The patient urinates approximately every two to three hours and once at night, showing good urinary control. Pelvic exercises and rehab have reportedly helped control her urine under stressful situations. She received a renal ultrasound on August 5th, 2008, which resulted normal, with no hydronephrosis, masses, or stones detected. The patient has had recurrent E. coli infections, with instances in November 2007 and May and July 2008.

The patient reported taking Tylenol PM for sleeplessness, an unspecified diuretic ("water pill"), an unspecified blood thinner, multivitamins, and folic acid. The doctor also found records of the patient taking Norvasc, Lanoxin, Diovan, and Atenolol for blood pressure management.

The patient, a 37-year-old left-handed male, presented with persistent and worsening symptoms of headaches, nausea, and vomiting for over a month. Despite an initial exam showing no evidence of bowel obstruction, the patient has not reported any improvement in symptoms. The patient's headaches are described as dull and constant, typically starting at the forehead and radiating to the back. They occur about six times a day and worsen upon sitting up, but improve somewhat with lying down or bending forward. Accompanying symptoms include blurred vision, photosensitivity, and phonophobia. The patient has ruled out blindness, positive visual phenomena, weakness, numbness, tingling, double vision, and speech disorders. Weight fluctuation has been noted, ranging from 163 to 148 pounds over the last three months, with the current weight at 154 pounds. The patient has also reported poor eating habits and loss of appetite in the last month.

The patient is a married woman living in a single-level home with her husband, who assists her with household chores. She reports being generally in good health, being a non-smoker, and occasionally enjoying a glass of wine with dinner. She used to exercise daily for about an hour or more, but stopped around June 2008 due to back pain. The patient works full time as a project manager, a role that involves extended periods of walking. Her husband is also reported to be in good health.

Summary of Dialogue: The patient enjoys traveling and has visited more than six countries in the past. However, they have not traveled outside the country for a couple of years. The patient plans to travel abroad in the future. There are no current health issues related to travel.
The patient denies experiencing any chest pain, but reports shortness of breath following physical exertion. They do not report any bladder, bowel, or bleeding issues.

The patient's mother passed away due to stomach cancer. His sister suffered from Alzheimer's disease and eventually succumbed to complications from pneumonia. The patient's father passed away in a car accident. The patient's brother died from mesothelioma, a condition attributed to his exposure to asbestos while working in shipyards. This history suggests potential genetic predisposition to cancer and Alzheimer's in the family.
The patient has a confirmed allergy to the antibiotic Cephalexin.
The patient has a history of past cigarette smoking but is currently a non-smoker. The patient has denied any alcohol consumption.

The 55-year-old patient, who has had a stroke in the past, visited the doctor accompanied by her power of attorney. She complained of an increasing urge to use the bathroom frequently, leading to episodes of urinary incontinence. The patient mentioned that she has been on medications including VESIcare and Enablex, but they have not shown any improvements yet. She denied having any blood in the urine, pain during urination, fever, chills, or bowel issues. However, she did note she uses several pairs of Depends a day due to incontinence. The patient reported that a voiding diary has not been kept. The doctor reviewed her urodynamic results from April 2008, which showed significant detrusor instability, involuntary urinary incontinence, and low bladder volumes. Her cystoscopy was unremarkable.
The patient disclosed a pre-existing condition of asthma.

The 41-year-old White male patient has a past medical history of HIV, high blood pressure, and high triglyceride levels. His recent lab results from August 2007, showed a CD4 count of 425 and viral load count less than 50. He recently had surgery to remove and clean an abscess in his left glute which is healing satisfactorily. The patient has also been newly diagnosed with diabetes and is exhibiting symptoms such as frequent urination and excessive thirst. He was initially given insulin while in hospital but because he could not afford it, he was subsequently prescribed Glucophage and glyburide, both of which he has taking as prescribed. The patient reports that he is feeling better overall.

The patient reported no known medical conditions in their history. They specifically denied having any history of depression or high blood pressure. The patient's recollection does not indicate any significant past medical conditions.

The patient has a family history of Huntington disease, which has affected both their mother and grandmother, both of whom passed away from the disease. The patient's two younger brothers also have the disease, with one currently undergoing an unspecified neurological treatment.
The patient's chart confirms he does not have any known drug allergies.
The patient confirmed that they have no known drug allergies.

The patient is married for ten years now. He reported that he neither smokes nor drinks alcohol, and that he does not use recreational drugs. The patient's lifestyle doesn't seem to involve habits such as smoking, drinking, or drug usage that could trigger health risks.

The patient attended a routine physical check-up. He reported a significant family history of disease, including lung cancer, ischemic heart disease, and congestive heart failure, which were the causative issues in the deaths of his father and mother, respectively, both in their eighties. He also mentioned that he has six sisters and two brothers who, to his knowledge, are in good health.

The 78-year-old patient has a history of hypertension and is currently managing it with daily dosages of 25mg hydrochlorothiazide and potassium chloride. All her recent intercranial lab work has come back negative. She reported no symptoms of chest pain, shortness of breath, dizzy spells, ankle swelling, or trouble breathing when sleeping, implying the medication seems to be controlling her hypertension well.

The 66-year-old female patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of dizziness. Initial assessment by the doctor indicated high blood pressure and tachycardia. The patient was accompanied by her husband. The doctor is yet to confirm if the patient has a history of hypertension and tachycardia.

The patient last visited the doctor about three months ago. She reported experiencing difficulty managing her diabetes, potentially exacerbated by recent upper and lower respiratory illnesses. These illnesses improved on their own without medical treatment. Her two week average glucose level is 191, indicating poor control. The patient mentioned issues with her infusion set that have been causing difficulties in blood sugar management. After receiving a correction bolus, her glucose levels dropped to a low level and then were raised back to a level slightly over 100 through intake of glucose and crackers. She reported feeling better after this adjustment. The patient has recently had minor changes in her diet due to travel and family visits, but reported no other known medical issues interfering with her glucose control. She is confident that she can manage her condition independently.

The patient is taking Synthroid for hypothyroidism. The patient discontinued Aspirin a week ago. The patient also confirmed the discontinuation of Terazosin, Lisinopril, and Atenolol, based on the advice of their cardiologist (Doctor X) several weeks ago.

The doctor performed a routine physical exam of the patient's eyes, ears, and oral cavity. The examination of the eyes showed them to be healthy with no lesions on the lids, brows or corners of the eyes, no abnormalities in extra ocular movements, and no signs of glaucoma or cataracts. The sclerae and pupils appeared normal. On examination of the ears, they were found to be of normal set and shape with a healthy tympanic membrane and no issues related to hearing or tinnitus. The check for respiratory issues such as cough, cold or sinus congestion yielded negative. The oral examination showed no abnormalities and the patient mentioned having recently visited a dentist for dental work.

The patient discontinued drug use at 25 years old and had one relapse, but has been clean for over 10 years. Despite knowing the health risks, the patient continues to be a heavy smoker which is especially concerning due to their chronic bronchitis.

The patient appears to be in good spirits and maintains high energy levels. The patient has not gained any weight since her last visit, which might be owing to her high energy levels. The primary caregiver mentioned that the patient had issues with constipation. The doctor did not find any changes in the patient's breathing. The doctor recommended an increased protein intake in the patient's daily diet for weight gain, and provided a handout to the caregiver with meal suggestions and tips for maintaining consistent mealtimes.
The patient is married and lives with his wife. The patient does not smoke. Other pertinent social history has already been gathered by the nursing team.
The patient is divorced and currently works as a homemaker. The patient indicated that they do not smoke or drink.

The patient, a 72-year-old woman, was admitted in May 2009 and has a history of hypertension. On June 18, 2009, she experienced severe abdominal pain, diarrhoea and cramps, which were suspected to be due to a C Diff infection. This was based on a CT scan of her abdomen showing diffuse colitis. To manage these symptoms, she was put on IV antibiotics, specifically Flagyl and Levaquin, along with IV Reglan to treat her vomiting. Despite treatment, her white blood cell count remains high, indicating persistent infection. Currently, the patient is no longer experiencing nausea or vomiting but still has diarrhoea, leading to weakness. Other than persistent diarrhoea and weakness, she does not report any other symptoms.

The doctor inquired about any discomfort or excess mucous accumulation in the patient's throat, to which the patient responded negatively. Additionally, the patient denied experiencing any throat soreness.

The patient has been mobile without any issues and has followed the doctor's instruction to remain Nil per Os (NPO). As of the June 10, 2009 visit, there are no new symptoms. The patient reports tenderness at the surgical site but is otherwise in good health post-procedure. The doctor confirmed that the surgery went well and the patient should be able to eat again soon.
The patient reported no known history of major medical conditions, such as depression or cancer.
The patient has received their annual flu vaccination. However, they have not received the Pneumonia vaccine this year.
